dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So, a fourth stimulus package is on the table, and the Trump administration is pushing for billions more for testing and the CDC. That's a pretty big shift, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, a fourth stimulus package is on the table, and the Trump administration is pushing for billions more for testing and the C D C. That's a pretty big shift, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As Congress races to come together on a fifth coronavirus stimulus package with cases skyrocketing across the country, the Trump administration is actively working to block billions of dollars in federal funding for testing and the Centers for Disease Control, according to a new report from the Washington Post.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it's interesting that they're specifically urging Senate Democrats to include that funding boosts in their proposal this week.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it's interesting that they're specifically urging Senate Democrats to include that funding boosts in their proposal this week.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Post reports that Trump administration officials are trying to persuade Senate Republicans to remove billions of dollars in funding for coronavirus testing and the CDC from a stimulus proposal GOP senators will release this week.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, like, the New York Times report mentions that some Democrats are actually delighted by this White House request. That's not something you hear every day.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, like, the New York Times report mentions that some Democrats are actually delighted by this White House request. That's not something you hear every day.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The White House request has reportedly angered GOP senators, and some Republicans have pushed back, adamant the funding should stay in the bill.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And Trump's been praising CDC director Robert Redfield lately too—agreeing with mask guidance and giving the agency control over data. It feels like a coordinated message.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Trump's been praising C D C director Robert Redfield lately too-agreeing with mask guidance and giving the agency control over data. It feels like a coordinated message.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Post report comes as Trump continues to swipe at the CDC: on Friday, the president said he doesnt agree with the CDC director Robert Redfields mask guidance and earlier, the Trump administration stripped the agency of control over coronavirus data and blocked Redfield from testifying to Congress on school reopenings.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But then you've got Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin pushing to end stimulus checks and the $600 unemployment boost. So there's still tension there.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then you've got Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin pushing to end stimulus checks and the six hundred dollars unemployment boost. So there's still tension there.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin is pressing for another round of stimulus checks and even extending some variation of the $600 expanded unemployment program in a next bill, while other administration officials want to work around the edges with proposals like a payroll tax holiday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. And uh, the Times also says they want funding for the State Department and Pentagon pandemic efforts? That's a new angle.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. And uh, the Times also says they want funding for the State Department and Pentagon pandemic efforts? That's a new angle.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Trump administration is also attempting to reduce funding in the GOP proposal for the State Department and the Pentagon to fight the pandemic, the Post reports.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but despite all this talk about testing funding, Mick Mulvaney wrote an op-ed claiming the U.S. has no testing problem at all. Which, uh, seems out of step.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but despite all this talk about testing funding, Mick Mulvaney wrote an op-ed claiming the U.S. has no testing problem at all. Which, uh, seems out of step.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Former White House Chief of Staff Mick Mulvaney penned an op-ed in CNBC this week in which he argued the U.S. still has a testing problem.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, especially when labs are taking hours to deliver results. It's like two different realities happening at once.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, especially when labs are taking hours to deliver results. It's like two different realities happening at once.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This week, the Washington Post reported that some testing sites are taking five to seven days to deliver results to patients.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And Senate Democrats are aiming for around $5 billion just for testing and contact tracing. But some in the White House think previous money's already spent.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Senate Democrats are aiming for around five dollars billion just for testing and contact tracing. But some in the White House think previous money's already spent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The amount of money Senate Republicans want to include for testing and contact tracing, according to the Washington Post. The Post reports that some White House officials believe money approved for testing has been unspent (the coronavirus spending package passed in April included $25 billion for testing.)

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So where does that leave us? A unified front on some things, but still major disagreements on others, like the overall price tag—some want it over $3 trillion.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So where does that leave us? A unified front on some things, but still major disagreements on others, like the overall price tag-some want it over three dollars trillion.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Some Republicans and White House officials reportedly want to keep the price tag of a next bill under $1 trillion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. Chuck Schumer's even been praising the Republican proposal publicly, which is… surprising, to say the least.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. Chuck Schumer's even been praising the Republican proposal publicly, which is... surprising, to say the least.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We have not heard a peep from McConnell or the Republicans or the administration on any proposal, even though we've been asking for weeks and weeks and weeks, Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) said on a conference call Friday about the GOP stimulus bill, CNN reported.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's a weird mix of collaboration and conflict. I wonder how this plays out before the August recess.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's a weird mix of collaboration and conflict. I wonder how this plays out before the August recess.

artist_script:
HostA: So, a fourth stimulus package is on the table, and the Trump administration is pushing for billions more for testing and the CDC. That’s a pretty big shift, right?
HostB: Yeah, and it’s interesting that they’re specifically urging Senate Democrats to include that funding boosts in their proposal this week.
HostA: Right, like, the New York Times report mentions that some Democrats are actually delighted by this White House request. That’s not something you hear every day.
HostB: And Trump’s been praising CDC director Robert Redfield lately too—agreeing with mask guidance and giving the agency control over data. It feels like a coordinated message.
HostA: But then you’ve got Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin pushing to end stimulus checks and the $600 unemployment boost. So there’s still tension there.
HostB: For sure. And uh, the Times also says they want funding for the State Department and Pentagon pandemic efforts? That’s a new angle.
HostA: Yeah, but despite all this talk about testing funding, Mick Mulvaney wrote an op-ed claiming the U.S. has no testing problem at all. Which, uh, seems out of step.
HostB: Right, especially when labs are taking hours to deliver results. It’s like two different realities happening at once.
HostA: And Senate Democrats are aiming for around $5 billion just for testing and contact tracing. But some in the White House think previous money’s already spent.
HostB: So where does that leave us? A unified front on some things, but still major disagreements on others, like the overall price tag—some want it over $3 trillion.
HostA: Exactly. Chuck Schumer’s even been praising the Republican proposal publicly, which is… surprising, to say the least.
HostB: It’s a weird mix of collaboration and conflict. I wonder how this plays out before the August recess.
